thread.title: Lehigh grad to play for U.S. team
thread.title_full: Lehigh grad to play for U.S. team - The Morning Call

author: mcall.com
title: Lehigh grad to play for U.S. team
text:
Manny Oudin knew that Gina Lewandowski was a fine soccer player when he coached her at Lehigh University in the mid-2000s, but he had no idea how high her athletic ceiling was at the time.
"No," he said. "I honestly didn't have any idea (how good she could be) either during the recruiting process or her time at Lehigh. She had aspirations of going to play overseas, but she was always focused and a leader of our team."
Oudin, now the athletic director at Moravian Academy, learned Friday just how high the ceiling is for Lewandowski, the former Allentown Central Catholic star who has been a professional in Germany for several years.
Earlier this week, Lewandowski was called up to the U.S. Women' National Team roster and is expected to dress for the USWNT's friendly versus Brazil.
Game time is 2:30 p.m. Sunday. It will be televised by Fox Sports 1.
The callup is sweet for several reasons. In 2012, she was called up to the USWNT as it prepared for a friendly against China and as then-coach Pia Sundhage prepared for the London Olympics.
But as Lewandowski prepared for a trip to meet the team as it trained at Princeton University, she learned that she would not be let out of her contract by her German club, Bayern Munich, which had several important games coming up.
Lewandowski, 30, is a midfielder and defender. She has played with and against the best female players in the world, but this will be her first time playing at the national team vs. national team level.
"Gina and I talk online periodically," Oudin said. "I obviously follow what she's done. It's been great to see the success she's had â€” both personally and the teams she's been on have done very well."
Lewandowski was traveling from Seattle to Florida on Friday and could not be reached for this story.
"When she talked about going over there, I thought it was great," Oudin said. "It's been a little frustrating for me, someone who's known her since she was 17 years old. Playing with and against some of the best women's players in the world, I was hoping she would get the opportunity a lot sooner. To get this opportunity is a great tribute to her longevity as a player."
Tim Shoemaker is a freelance writer.
